SUBSECTION.NAME: Using Integers Only
SUBSECTION.TEXT: The Egyptians did not have a concept of numbers other than integers. Even in their fractions they were represented by integers placed in a certain order. Likewise, when we deal with fractions we use 2 integers placed vertically and a line between them to show which is the numerator and the denominator. Hence, we will also limit ourselves to using only integers as we get into the programming. Though computers can represent non-integer numbers, they can be complicated to work with.

As we see below, the numbers in the powers of 2 are special to the Egyptians. Likewise, the binary system is also very relevant to computer science. When looking at the lower levels of a computer, we see that computers only understand 0s and 1s which are numbers with a base of 2, instead of our usual base 10 in mathematics that we use. This is also known as machine language. When we program, we use identifiers and syntax that we can read and understand. As we compile, these programs are converted into 0s and 1s for computers to understand and return the result.
